TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit Viewport2DVisual3D extends System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Visual3D

Docs.summary: Renders the 2-D children within the specified 3-D viewport bounds.

remarks.format:
## Remarks <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Viewport2DVisual3D> enables you to place interactive 2-D content on a 3-D object. Its counterpart is the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Viewport3DVisual> class, which is a 2-D visual with 3-D children.
<xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Viewport2DVisual3D> is introduced in the .NET Framework version 3.5.
## Examples The following example shows how to place a button, a 2-D object, on a 3-D object. Note that you must set the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Viewport2DVisual3D.IsVisualHostMaterial%2A> attached property on the material on which you wish to have the 2-D visual placed.
[!code-xaml[Viewport2DVisual3DExample#Viewport3D](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/Viewport2DVisual3DExample/CS/window1.xaml#viewport3d)]
For the complete sample, see [Interactive 2-D on 3-D Sample](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=160007).

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor() cil managed

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

remarks.format: ## Remarks <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Viewport2DVisual3D.%23ctor%2A> is introduced in the .NET Framework version 3.5.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a cached representation of the .
Docs.value: A that holds a cached representation of the .

remarks.format:
## Remarks Set the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Viewport2DVisual3D.CacheMode%2A> property when you need to increase performance for content that is time-consuming to render. For more information, see <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCache>.
The <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Viewport2DVisual3D> class projects 3-D content into 2-D to size the 2-D content in the 3-D element correctly.
Because caching always relies on the elementâ€™s size, instead of the transform applied to it, when you set the <xref:System.Windows.Media.CacheMode> property, initially your content may appear pixilated. This is because it is being upsampled to a much larger size than it was cached at. You can correct this situation by increasing the local size of your 2-D visual by setting the <xref:System.Windows.FrameworkElement.Height%2A> or <xref:System.Windows.FrameworkElement.Width%2A> properties. Also, you can increase the <xref:System.Windows.Media.BitmapCache.RenderAtScale%2A> on the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Viewport2DVisual3D.CacheMode%2A> until the content reaches an acceptable level of clarity.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static initonly class System.Windows.DependencyProperty CacheModeProperty

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the material that describes the appearance of the 3-D object.

remarks.format:
## Remarks You must set the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Viewport2DVisual3D.IsVisualHostMaterial%2A> attached property on the material on which you wish to have the 2-D visual placed.
<xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Viewport2DVisual3D.Material%2A> is introduced in the .NET Framework version 3.5.
## Examples The following example shows how to specify the material where the 2-D visual (the button) should be placed by setting this property and also setting the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Viewport2DVisual3D.IsVisualHostMaterial%2A> attached property to `true`:
[!code-xaml[Viewport2DVisual3DExample#Viewport3D](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/Viewport2DVisual3DExample/CS/window1.xaml#viewport3d)]
For the complete sample, see [Interactive 2-D on 3-D Sample](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=160007).

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the 2-D visual to be placed on the 3-D object.
Docs.value: The visual to be placed on the 3-D object.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The visual is first applied to the <xref:System.Windows.Media.VisualBrush>, which is then used on the 3-D object.
<xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Viewport2DVisual3D.Visual%2A> is introduced in the .NET Framework version 3.5.
## Examples The following example shows how to place a button, a 2-D object, on a 3-D object:

For the complete sample, see [Interactive 2-D on 3-D Sample](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=160007).
